title: Vue.js 3.0 “One Piece” release
description: "The 3.0 release represents over 2 years of development efforts, featuring 30+ RFCs, 2,600+ commits, 628 pull requests from 99 contributors, plus a tremendous amount of development and documentation work outside of the core repo."

title: Rome first beta release
description: Rome, a new linter for JavaScript and TypeScript, is released.

title: ECMAScript 2020
description: Introduction of BigInt for arbitrary-sized integers, new null coalescing syntax, and a name which always refers to the global object.

title: JavaScript makes it into space
description: The SpaceX Dragon launch brings JavaScript to space! The Dragon 2 flight interface was built using Chromium and JavaScript along with C++ for flight computers.

title: WebStorm turns 10
description: The WebStorm team celebrates WebStorm’s tenth birthday while working on a new IDE version and trying to get to used to the new “working from home” reality.

title: Deno 1.0 released
description: Deno finally sees the light of day with its first public release. It’s still not clear whether it’s going to become the next big thing but the hopes are high.

title: Playwright announced
description: “Today we are announcing Playwright – our take on fixing end-to-end testing. Playwright is a cross-browser automation library to write tests that are fast, reliable and capable.”

title: Angular 9.0.0 with Ivy
description: Ivy, the new default compiler and runtime, was one of the most exciting enhancements in this Angular update.

title: WebAssembly 1.0 and W3C core specification arrive
description: The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) describes version 1.0 of the core WebAssembly standard, a low-level code format designed for efficient execution and compact representation.

title: Optional chaining and nullish coalescing make their way to ES2020
description: Both proposals were moved to stage 4. The language syntax was extended with two new operators ?. and ?? which help to write safer code.

title: Hermes goes open source
description: Facebook open sources Hermes, a JavaScript engine optimized for running React Native on Android.

title: ECMAScript 2019
description: New features include Array.prototype.flat, Array.prototype.flatMap, and changes to Array.sort and Object.fromEntries.

title: GraalVM 19.0
description: GraalVM, a runtime that removes the isolation between programming languages, is ready for production use. It lets you run JavaScript with Java, Ruby, Python, R, and any other languages which support the Truffle APIs integration.

title: Svelte 3 released
description: The Svelte framework gets a major update and starts gaining popularity. Many developers try to understand why this update is so important and share their thoughts with the community.

title: Plans on Microsoft Edge shared
description: Microsoft adopts Chromium as the web platform for Microsoft Edge desktop. Later, the browser becomes available on macOS.

title: React hooks announced
description: Sophie Alpert, Dan Abramov, and Ryan Florence define the problems with “wrapper hell, huge components and confusing classes” and introduce React hooks as a solution

title: ECMAScript 2018
description: Rest/spread operator for object literals, asynchronous iteration and additions to RegExp.

title: Ryan Dahl presents the prototype of Deno
description: Ryan Dahl, the creator of Node.js, gives a talk at JSConf EU 2018 and introduces Deno, a new runtime for JavaScript and TypeScript. The talk is called 10 Things I Regret About Node.js and is still available on YouTube.

title: TensorFlow.js: ML in JavaScript
description: Sara Robinson and Josh Gordon introduce TensorFlow.js, an open-source library that can be used to define, train, and run machine learning models entirely in the browser.

title: Puppeteer v1.0.0
description: Version 1.0.0 of Puppeteer, a Node library providing high-level API to control Chrome or Chromium, is released to the world.

title: The creation of Sapper
description: Sapper, a new Next.js-style framework, is introduced.

title: Flash EOL
description: In July 2017, Adobe announce that they will stop updating and distributing Flash Player after December 31, 2020.

title: ECMAScript 2017
description: Improvements include Object.values, Object.entries and Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors functions for easier object manipulation, async/await constructions which use generators and promises as well as concurrency and atomic features.

title: Prettier 1.0 released
description:
Christopher Chedeau and James Long publish a blog post about Prettier 1.0 release.
“It started as an experiment but it clearly resonated with a lot of people, amassing ~7000 GitHub stars and over 100,000 monthly npm downloads in just two months.”

title: Initial Temporal proposal commit
description: Maggie Johnson-Pint proposes Temporal, a global Object that acts as a top-level namespace and brings a modern date/time API to ECMAScript

title: Nest.js made available on npm
description: Kamil Mysliwiec creates Nest.js, a web framework for Node.js. Its architecture is heavily inspired by Angular.

title: Version 1 of Svelte
description: Rich Harris publishes “Frameworks without the framework: why didn’t we think of this sooner?” and introduces Svelte.js, another JavaScript framework.

title: Nuxt.js 0.0.1
description: A minimalistic framework for server-rendered Vue applications inspired by Next.js.

title: Vue.js 2.0 with JSX support
description: “Today I am thrilled to announce the official release of Vue.js 2.0: Ghost in the Shell. After 8 alphas, 8 betas and 8 rcs (a total coincidence!), Vue.js 2.0 is ready for production!”

title: Angular is born
description:
The same team that built AngularJS rewrites it and introduces Angular 2, written in TypeScript.
At this point, quite a few teams have abandoned AngularJS in favor of libraries like React. Some developers even wrote break-up letters to their once-beloved framework.

title: async/await
description: The async functions proposal is moved to stage 4.

title: ECMAScript 2016 finalized
description: This update comes with async and await keywords for asynchronous programming, block-scoping of variables and functions, destructing patterns of variables, among many other features.

title: First commits to the TC39 proposals repository
description: The repository contains information about the stages of proposals to ECMAScript

title: Announcing AWS Lambda with Node.js
description: JavaScript is available for serverless.

title: left-pad and npm
description: Azer Koçulu unpublished the kik package along with 272 other packages. One of the affected packages is left-pad.

title: WebKit’s B3 JIT compiler is released
description: The Bare Bones Backend, or “B3”, replaces LLVM as the low-level optimizer in the FTL JIT.

title: ChakraCore open sourced
description: The core components of the JavaScript engine powering Microsoft Edge become open source.

title: GraphQL
description: After three years of internal use, Facebook introduces GraphQL, a query language for APIs and a runtime for serving those queries with existing data.

title: Glimmer
description: Ember.js 1.13.0 gets the Glimmer rendering engine.

title: Initial release of Redux
description: Dan Abramov began writing the first implementation of Redux while preparing for a conference talk at React Europe. He later invites Andrew Clark to collaborate with him.

title: ES2015, big ECMAScript update
description:
This update includes arrow function expressions, let and const keywords, class declaration, promises, generators, and many other improvements.
Starting from this edition, ECMAScript will also get regular updates each year.

title: Polymer 1.0
description: One of the major libraries for building web applications using Web Components.

title: NativeScript 1.0.0 released
description: NativeScript is an open-source framework that allows you to write native apps for Android, iOS and Windows Phone using JavaScript.

title: VS Code released
description: Microsoft announces Visual Studio Code, a new member of the Visual Studio family, at its annual Build conference. The new code editor is built on the Electron framework.

title: TypeScript and AtScript languages converge
description: Google and Microsoft announce that the TypeScript and AtScript languages have been converged, and Angular 2 will be built with TypeScript.

title: io.js: Node.js split in two
description: Unhappy with the stewardship of Node’s official sponsor, part of the Node.js team fork the Node.js project and create their own version of it, called io.js. The main differences include a proper semver and an updated V8 engine with ES6 features. In the long run, they hope that both projects will be merged back together and that it will help the JavaScript community move forward.

title: Flow, a new static type checker
description: “We have designed Flow so developers can reap its benefits without losing the feel of coding in JavaScript.”

title: AtScript introduced
description: Miško Hevery introduces AtScript to the world and talks about the future and the past of AngularJS.

title: First commit to Babel.js
description: Sebastian McKenzie starts a new project to help with converting the new version of ECMAScript into versions that older JavaScript engines can process

title: Start of modern decorators journey in TC39
description: Yehuda Katz presents aspects of common use cases not yet covered by the ES6 class.

title: Vue.js released by Evan You
description: “I figured, what if I could just extract the part that I really liked about Angular and build something really lightweight without all the extra concepts involved? I was also curious as to how its internal implementation worked. I started this experiment just trying to replicate this minimal feature set, like declarative data binding. That was basically how Vue started.”

title: Koa 0.0.1 on npm
description: The team behind Express designs Koa, a new web framework for Node.js.

title: Espruino source code released
description: Gordon Williams releases the source code of Espruino, a JavaScript interpreter for microcontrollers.

title: First commit to the core-js repository
description: Denis Pushkarev starts the core-js project, a modular standard library for JavaScript.

title: GitHub introduces Electron
description: GitHub develops Atom Shell, a framework that will later be renamed to Electron. The goal is to “create a straightforward framework that will allow people to use web technologies to build cross-platform desktop apps with all of the native trimmings.”

title: Work on ESLint started
description: After contributing to JSHint, Nicholas C. Zakas decides to create a new JavaScript linting and style checking tool. Originally called JSCheck, this tool will later be renamed to ESLint.

title: sinopia v0.1.0
description: Work begins on a private/caching npm repository.

title: React Native
description: React Native begins as a hackathon project in the summer of 2013.

title: React goes open source
description:
Tom Occhino and Jordan Walke introduce React at JSConf US 2013. React becomes an open-source project.
The audience at the conference is skeptical. Some people think that React is a huge step backward. This happened because most of the conference attendees were “early adopters” and “early majority”, while React was targeted at “innovators”.

title: Blink announced
description: Blink is a new open-source rendering engine based on WebKit.

title: asm.js in Firefox Nightly
description: asm.js, a subset of JavaScript later superseded by WebAssembly, is announced to be shipped with Firefox 22.

title: TypeScript tooling starts to catch up
description: WebStorm is among the first cross-platform IDEs to get support for TypeScript.

title: Firefox OS
description:
The first commercial devices with Firefox OS, whose UI layer is written entirely in JavaScript, are announced at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona.

In September 2016, Mozilla will announce that work on Firefox OS has ceased.

title: Opera moves to WebKit
description: The Opera team announces that they will use WebKit as the rendering engine and V8 as the JavaScript engine for all new products.

title: ECMAScript Internationalization API Specification 1st Edition
description:
“The ECMAScript Internationalization API provides key language-sensitive functionality as a complement to the ECMAScript Language Specification, 5.1 edition or successor. Its functionality has been selected from that of well-established internationalization APIs such as those of the Internationalization Components for Unicode (ICU) library, of the .NET framework, or of the Java platform.
The API was developed by an ad-hoc group established by ECMA TC39 in September 2010 based on a proposal by Nebojša Ćirić and Jungshik Shin.”

title: Promises/A+ specification initial commit
description: Work begins on an “open standard for sound, interoperable JavaScript promises”.

title: TypeScript made public
description:
After 2 years of internal development, Microsoft introduces a JavaScript superset called TypeScript. They developed TypeScript in an attempt to make JavaScript useful for large-scale development.
The first impressions of TypeScript were controversial. For example, Miguel de Icaza highlighted a number of advantages but also raised concerns about the lack of support for TypeScript in tooling other than Microsoft Visual Studio.

title: Bower initial release
description: Twitter creates Bower, a package manager for the web, as part of their open-source effort. It attracts considerable support from private contributors.

title: PLV8
description: Jerry Sievert writes, “I had a crazy thought. Don’t all good ideas start with that phrase? Well, this one was suitably crazy: why not build my own version of MongoDB right on top of Postgres? It sounds a little far-fetched, but in all honesty it’s pretty simple."

title: UglifyJS initial commit
description: One of the most popular JavaScript minification tools comes to life.

title: Meteor officially launched
description: Initially introduced under the name Skybreak, Meteor, a framework and application server for building websites in JavaScript, is officially soft-launched.

title: Work begins on Johnny-Five
description: Rick Waldron starts working on Johnny-Five, a JavaScript robotics programming framework.

title: webpack module bundler
description: webpack, a new static module bundler for JavaScript applications, is introduced

title: UMD information centralized
description: A group of people creates a new project in an attempt to centralize the information on UMD patterns.

title: Dart unveiled
description: Lars Bak and Gilad Bracha from Google give a talk at GOTO Aarhus and present a new programming language called Dart.

title: Work begins on the first React prototype
description: Jordan Walke starts working on FaxJS, an early prototype of React.

title: Google releases WebRTC source code
description: The WebRTC project provides web browsers and mobile applications with Real-Time Communications (RTC) capabilities via simple APIs.

title: WebKit Remote Debugging
description: WebKit Remote Debugging marks a new era for mobile browser debugging. It later becomes the Chrome DevTools Protocol

title: Traceur presented
description: Traceur, a “JavaScript-to-JavaScript compiler written in JavaScript” is announced.

title: The first commit of Ember.js
description: The first commit to the repository that will become Ember.js is made on April 30, 2011. About two and a half years later, the Ember.js core team announces the release of Ember 1.0.

title: IE 9 with JIT compilation
description: The 32-bit version of IE 9 gets a new JScript engine named Chakra, which converts JScript into machine code before running it

title: WebGL™ 1.0
description: “Royalty-free specification brings OpenGL ES 2.0 3D graphics functionality to HTML5; Adopted by Apple, Google, Mozilla and Opera with implementations shipping today.”

title: Samsung Smart TVs
description: Samsung begins actively promoting its Smart TVs. Tutorials on how to create TV apps using the JavaScript template appear on the Internet.

title: IE6 Countdown
description: Microsoft launches a website called IE6 Countdown which displays the usage of Internet Explorer 6 around the world to motivate people to upgrade.

title: RxJS first publication on npm
description: A set of libraries for composing asynchronous and event-based programs with the use of observable collections.

title: Browserify v0.0.1
description: Browserify equips browsers with require() for npm packages.

title: PhantomJS: WebKit-based JavaScript-driven tool
description: After several years of development work, Ariya Hidayat releases a new WebKit-based browser without a GUI.

title: AngularJS created
description: AngularJS is introduced a week after Backbone.js.

title: File API in Chrome
description: The first release of one of the most important parts of HTML 5 is included in a Google Chrome browser update.

title: Backbone.js released
description: Jeremy Ashkenas releases Backbone.js, designed specifically for building single-page apps with JavaScript.

title: Chrome, “Release Early, Release Often”
description:
The Chrome team decides to reduce the release cycle time.
This will later influence the release cycles of all other major browsers.

title: WebStorm 1.0, a new JavaScript IDE by JetBrains
description: Previously known under its working name of Web IDE, WebStorm 1.0 is released with support for HTML, CSS, and JavaScript

title: Test262: ECMAScript Test Suite initial contribution
description: ECMA International starts developing a test suite for the ECMA specifications.

title: npm was born
description: Isaac Schlueter invents a new package manager for JavaScript

title: Initial commit of CoffeeScript
description: On December 14, 2009, Jeremy Ashkenas commits a bunch of files to GitHub with the message: “initial commit of the mystery language”. Drawing inspiration from Python, Ruby, and some other languages, he started working on CoffeeScript, a new programming language that compiles into JavaScript.

title: End of dark times for ECMAScript
description: Using version 3.1 as a starting point, ECMAScript gets revamped after a very long break. The new version includes such important features as strict mode, getters and setters, and JSON support.

title: Chrome extensions in beta
description: "Google Chrome extensions accomplish all these goals: they are as easy to create as web pages, easy to install, and each extension runs in its own process to avoid crashing or significantly slowing down the browser."

title: The rise of Node.js
description: Ryan Dahl gives a talk at JSConf 2009 and introduces Node.js, a JavaScript runtime built on top of Chrome’s V8 JavaScript engine. The hypothetical JavaScript Everywhere paradigm becomes a reality.

title: Closure Compiler and related tools introduced
description: Closure Compiler, Closure Library, Closure Templates, and Closure Inspector get open sourced. These tools started as 20% projects and hundreds of Googlers contributed to them.

title: First underscore.js commit
description: Jeremy Ashkenas starts the underscore.js project.

title: RequireJS module loader
description: The primordial parts of the RequireJS loader begin to take form in September 2009, with many releases through October 2011, when 1.0 is introduced.

title: Work on Express.js started
description: TJ Holowaychuk makes the initial commit to the repository called expressjs, which will later become a home for a popular Node.js framework.

title: PhoneGap created
description: PhoneGap brings HTML5 and JavaScript to mobile applications in iOS and Android, giving rise to the new cross-platform application category.

title: CommonJS project started
description: Kevin Dangoon sets up a new ServerJS group trying to standardize the module ecosystem for JavaScript outside of the web browser. The project was later renamed to CommonJS.

title: “When can I use” is born
description: Alexis Deveria publicly announces a page that allows you to find out which browser supports which features.

title: Google Chrome: a fresh take on the browser
description: To “help drive innovation on the web”, Google launches the beta version of Google Chrome, along with a new JavaScript engine, V8. The announcement is accompanied by this comic book.

title: Raphaël released
description: Dmitry Baranovskiy releases a JavaScript library for working with vector graphics.

title: Public announcement of termination of ES4 and start of Harmony project
Discussions around WebSocket
description: Michael Carter leads a series of discussions that later result in the first version of the protocol known as WebSocket.

title: JavaScript: The Good Parts book
description: Douglas Crockford speaks at Konfabulator Developer Day 2007 and delivers a keynote called JavaScript: The Good Parts. A year later, this becomes the title of a book by O'Reilly Media.

title: HTML5 first public working draft
description: W3C publishes the specification for the 5th major revision of HTML

title: Ext JS 1.0 released
description: Version 1.0 of Ext JS, a framework for building interactive cross-platform web applications with Ajax, DHTML and DOM, is released.

title: First iPhone launched, no Flash support
description: Steve Jobs introduces the first iPhone. The phone uses a mobile version of the Safari browser and has no support for Adobe Flash Player. Later, Jobs shares his thoughts on Flash and reveals the reasons behind the decision not to support it.

title: Microsoft restarts IE development
description: Internet Explorer gets its first major update since 2001.

title: CouchDB Alpha released
description: Damien Katz unveils CouchDB Alpha 1. He has been working on it since 2005.

title: Google Web Toolkit made available
description: Google introduces one of the first toolchains for compiling Java to JavaScript.

title: YUI Library announced
description: The Yahoo! User Interface Library contains a lot of components and includes YUI Compressor, one of the first minifiers for JavaScript code.

title: Initial release of jQuery
description: John Resig makes the initial release of jQuery, a JavaScript library that makes it easier to navigate and manipulate the HTML DOM

title: Firebug 0.2
description: Joe Hewitt releases the single-tab console with Ajax logging.

title: Opera Mini launched in Germany
description: Opera Software launches Opera Mini, a web browser for mobile phones, on the German market.

title: Dojo Toolkit 0.1
description: Alex Russell, Dylan Schiemann, David Schontzler, and some other folks release the 0.1 version of Dojo, a JavaScript toolkit designed to ease the development of cross-platform, Ajax-based applications and web sites. The first stable version is yet to come in 2007.

title: Apple open sources WebKit
description: Apple announces the immediate availability of the WebKit Open Source Project, their fork of KHTML

title: Adobe Photoshop CS2 released with JavaScript as one of its scripting languages
description: “All of the Adobe Creative Suite 2 applications, including Adobe Photoshop CS2, use ExtendScript, Adobe’s extended implementation of JavaScript. ExtendScript files are distinguished by the .jsx extension. ExtendScript offers all standard JavaScript features, plus additional features and utilities.”

title: Prototype.js created
description: Prototype is a JavaScript framework that aims to ease the development of dynamic web applications. The framework offers extensive Ajax support, higher-order programming constructs, and easy DOM manipulation.

title: Jesse James Garrett coins the term Ajax
description: Jesse introduces the new term in an article titled “Ajax: A New Approach to Web Applications”, based on techniques used on Google pages.

title: The rise of MDN
description: Deb Richardson joins Mozilla Corporation and launches the initial Mozilla Developer Network in March 2005

title: Safari introduces <canvas&gt
description: “Another extension we made to HTML is a new element called the canvas. The way it works is that you can invoke a method called getContext on the canvas and then you have access to a whole range of 2d drawing calls.”

title: WHATWG Formation
description: Apple, Mozilla, and Opera form the WHATWG community in response to the slow development of W3C Web standards and the W3C’s decision to abandon HTML in favor of XML-based technologies.

title: Beta release of Gmail
description: Google publicly announces Gmail, launching the Ajax (even though the term wasn’t coined yet) and web application era. Its release on April 1 made some people think that the announcement was a prank.

title: Apple introduces Safari and WebKit
description: In a speech at Macworld Expo, Steve Jobs unveils a new Macintosh browser named Safari. The browser is based on Apple’s internal fork of the KHTML rendering engine called WebKit.

title: Mozilla Firefox released
description: Internet Explorer, which has dominated the web browser market since the early 2000s, is about to start losing a part of its market share to a new web browser, Mozilla Firefox.

title: JSLint
description: JSLint, the “grandfather of all JavaScript syntax checkers”, is introduced

title: Internet Explorer 6 released
description: This will be the last major update to Internet Explorer for the next 5 years. Despite dominating the market, this version of Internet Explorer was widely criticized for its security issues and lack of support for modern web standards. It even got into some of the “worst tech products of all time” lists, being labeled as “the least secure software on the planet.”

title: The first JSON message is sent
Opera browser goes free
description: Opera, the “third force in the browser wars”, is made available for free download from December 6, 2000, with the launch of Opera 5.0.

title: KHTML rewritten
description: KHTML, a browser engine developed by the KDE project and the ancestor of WebKit, is included in KDE 2.0.

title: Flash Player 5 released with ActionScript
description: Flash Player 5 includes the first version of ActionScript. This version is influenced by JavaScript and the ECMA-262 standard, and supports the standard’s object model and many of its core data types.

title: XSS mentioned in CERT®
description: Back in the early 2000s, almost all popular web services suffered from XSS security vulnerabilities that allow attackers to inject client-side scripts into webpages viewed by other users.

title: ECMAScript 3 released
description: The new version gets regular expressions, try/catch exception handling, better error handling, and some other important enhancements

title: JSDoc debut
description: An early example using a Javadoc-like syntax to document JavaScript is released with the Netscape/Mozilla project Rhino, a JavaScript runtime system written in Java. The project includes a toy “JSDoc” HTML generator as an example of its JavaScript capabilities.

title: First steps to Ajax
description: With Internet Explorer 5.0, Microsoft releases the first version of XMLHttpRequest (XHR), an API for transferring data between a web browser and a web server.

title: Updates to ECMAScript 1
description: Some minor editorial changes to the ECMAScript 1 specification are made to keep it fully aligned with the ISO/IEC 16262 international standard.

title: Mozilla Project created
description: Netscape open sources its browser suite, which leads to the creation of the Mozilla Project

title: The first edition of ECMA-262 published
description: With the first edition of ECMAScript, browser vendors, among others, get a consistent set of guidelines for implementing the JavaScript language

title: CSS1 specifications by W3C
description: The World Wide Web Consortium releases a document specifying level 1 of the Cascading Style Sheet mechanism.

title: The beginning of JavaScript standardization
description: Netscape realizes that JavaScript needs to be standardized and submits a proposal to ECMA International. Brendan Eich later shares the story behind this at an industry conference.

title: JavaScript gets its first dialect
description: Internet Explorer, the recently introduced browser by Microsoft, gets its own reverse-engineered alternative to JavaScript and names it JScript. Two almost identical languages, JScript and JavaScript, now exist in parallel.

title: JavaScript: The Definitive Guide, published
description: David Flanagan writes one of the first books about JavaScript.

title: Netscape and Sun Microsystems announce JavaScript
description: In an attempt to make web pages dynamic, Brendan Eich from Netscape starts working on a new scripting language. The first version of this language is developed in ten days and is dubbed “Mocha”. Later it is renamed to LiveScript and finally to JavaScript.
